cons: There were absolutely no cons to working at the Tutoring and Learning Center at Joliet Junior College. Was the best working environment I have been part of.

review_title: Take the good with the bad
pros: Generous PTO for Professional level staff 20 sick days and 20 vacation days annually. Fair wage. Extremely affordable benefits. Flextime. Currently work from home 2 days per week, on-campus 3 days per week. Closed on Fridays in the summer (working M-Th 10 hour days). Free Parking. Safe campuses. Great technology. Microsoft 0365, WorkDay.
cons: Extremely focused on DEI. Leadership is primarily minority, by design. Difficult for Caucasian employees to advance. External applicants favored. Search committees often include ill-equipped members who are out of touch with the needs of the immediate area.

review_title: Stay away from iCampus.  Seriously, RUN AWAY.
pros: Low employee cost toward good healthcare, some super faculty, great staff, and wonderful students.
cons: iCampus is a vital department to the success of online education at JJC and is headed by management that is woefully incompetent in nearly all aspects. 7 full time employees have left this department of 3 full time positions in just over 3 years. Every one of them left because of mismanagement, personal attacks, and fallout from managerial narcissism. Management can be found most days pretending to be in charge of faculty supervision, snooping into faculty courses, changing content to their liking, and finding new ways to subvert accessibility compliance.  It's a depressing environment.  iCampus is where careers go to die.

pros: Good community, decent pay, flexible hours
cons: Sometimes expect too much from their workers

pros: None.  There simply is no benefit to working for this college.  If you get hired, you will immediately question your life choices that led you to this point.
cons: If you desire to be bullied throughout your day by ineffectual and lazy faculty and administration, JJC is the place for you!  If, however, you have any modicum of professional standards or integrity, it's probably best if you look for a different place of employment.  Remarkably lazy full time faculty run the school, protected by their claims of academic freedom and tenure.  Administration only makes itself known when they  grovel to and bootlick the vocal tyrannical faculty members.  Compliance to internal regulations and external laws is a fantasy.  As an example, faculty frequently outright refuse to comply with ADA regulations.  During a recent HLC site visit, administration lied to reviewers about quality control and data analysis.  Nepotism is rampant.  There are serious ethical and legal concerns over the forthcoming ERP adoption due to a Cabinet member's financial conflict of interest.  In short, everything is wrong, staff are woefully abused, and students suffer.  JJC is a depressing place to work for those that are conscientious employees.  If you expect to be treated with even the most rudimentary standards of professionalism, look elsewhere than JJC.

pros: Benefits are fairly good including plenty of sick time. Health insurance is solid and costs employees remarkably little. My own team is wonderful and truly a pleasure to work with, so I think the culture and atmosphere depends a lot on what area you work in. There's ample parking and campus is pretty convenient to get to by car. Working hours are reasonable.
cons: Staff are treated as second-rate (or even third-rate) employees. For full-time faculty, it's their way or the highway, quite literally, even if they're unequivocally wrong. Full-time faculty are permitted to berate, degrade, and even threaten staff and face few or no consequences, which is truly appalling and makes me (as staff) feel very undervalued. There's quite high turnover in administration, which makes it difficult to gain traction on anything. Some administrators seem very out of touch with the day to day operations of some parts of the college, to the extent that they'll call departments by the wrong name. Communication leaves something to be desired. Don't expect to be promoted from within.

pros: The work is interesting the majority of the time, and most of your coworkers will be wonderful at best and bearable at worst. You are fairly self regulated and usually work at a relaxed pace.
cons: The pay is abysmal and the wage gap between different levels of tutors is huge (8.25-30.00 +). As a peer tutor, I was expected to perform at (and often above) the level of the professional tutors (tutors with bachelors degrees) all while being paid a third their hourly wage. Being the only person capable of tutoring math at or above the level of calculus, as well as the only one able to tutor physics of any kind, I was often saddled with the most difficult tutoring appointments. All this would have been fine had I also been treated in such a way that acknowledged my lower level of compensation.

pros:
- Great salary and benefits (compared to the region, not for comparable colleges)
- Good location for commuting
- Lots of generally nice and well-meaning people
cons:
- Toxic and negative work environment. 
- Board is clearly dysfunctional, patronizing, negative, and publicly criticizes and shows no appreciation for admins on a regular basis (see the online videos)
- HIghly politicized atmosphere. Those who are plugged into the Joliet political network get rewarded (a small group of 150 or so people who were born, raised, and continue to interact socially in Joliet). Those who are not plugged in get pushed our or are fired
- High leadership turnover - no one lasts too long
- Little to no job security
- Very little student success and bad learning results - the college exists to satisfy various individual and constituent political agends, not help students.

pros: The atmosphere was wonderful.  There are a lot of employees that enjoy their job and understand their job.  The new buildings are wonderful and modern looking.  The employee benefits are great.
cons: To many politics running the college. There are people who are employed simply to get a paycheck which is OK except those are not the lowest paid people in the university.  Some of the facilities are outdated.

pros: Little supervision, freedom to use teaching method of choice, formal evaluations that can be used as evidence of successful teaching
cons:
The math department at JJC does not care who is teaching their classes, as long as they get taught.  Their hiring process involved me showing up, being handed a book with some materials like a sample syllabus, and being given a class.  Imagine if students taking the class knew how little vetting went into the selection of their instructor!  

The adjunct situation at JJC works best if you are an older teacher, who teaches the same class each semester.  If you are not a favored teacher, good luck getting a decent schedule.  If the schedule doesn't work out for you, on to the next resume in the stack.  

The math departments' textbook selection leaves much to be desired.  They clearly use Michael Sullivan's texts because he works there.  His statistics book is particularly appalling.  It's as if the primary goal was to make a textbook that students are unable to read, while simultaneously using uninteresting, outdated examples.  

The pay is insulting.  We make less than minimum wage, and we have a union.

review_title: Very laid back place to work as long as you do your job.
job_title: Help Desk Analyst in Joliet, IL
pros: Health benefits time off your first year. They were willing to train and let you ease into the position. They have a cafe on site for lunch.
cons: Advancement is slow unless someone leaves. I would like to see growth plans is personal advancement is made. Promote from within to build loyalty to the college.

review_title: Not the best place to work if you are looking to advance your career.
pros: The people are great and some of the benefits for part-time employees are good.
cons: Management is out of touch and no way to move up in the organization unless you are well liked.

review_title: No opportunity for economic growth in this company. It's a dead-end job economically.
job_title: Adjunct Math Instructor in Joliet, IL
pros: Supervisors leave you alone. They pretty much ignore you, as they just don't seem to care very much; just as long as you have the numbers on roster.
cons: You'd almost have to be Jesus Christ Himself to get a full-time teaching job at JJC. I've stayed here much, much, much too long. I need something different; somewhere I'll be given the chance to grow and excel. JJC offers NOTHING!!!

review_title: A perfect place to let your career die on the vine.
pros: Best health benefits anywhere. Employees pay very little for the richest plan I've ever had in my career. That was NOT enough to keep me there.
cons:
President of the college has a goal of it being a "world-class organization." To be clear, we're talking about a junior college. In JOLIET. Any rational person knows that world-class educational institutions are the likes of Harvard, Yale, Brown, Oxford, etc. JJC leadership seems out of touch at best, and truly delusional at worst.

The majority of employees in human resources do not serve as a resource. I was denied bereavement benefits when my great-niece tragically died at the age of three months old, because she was not covered by their definition of "immediate family." Also, HR employees will harass you if they misinterpret your time-off requests, and tell you to stop yelling at them when you are so ballsy as to defend yourself. (I did raise my voice, but did not yell.) HR is not there to be a resource for the employees; they exist solely as a watchdog for management.

Leadership is lopsided; The Board of Trustees is over the President, and the Board agrees on almost nothing. Therefore, when decisions must be made, consensus is rare. Watching the Board fight is entertaining, though, which is a plus.

Pay is a mockery. I was paid about 20 percent less than the same position elsewhere. Some professional positions are classified as clerical - as was mine - so management can continue to over-work and under-pay employees. My supervisor routinely denied me overtime pay or comp time, telling me it wasn't available for my position, and this was in direct violation of policy.

In short, Joliet Junior College is probably great for long-term employees who don't want to work very hard. It is not good for someone who wants career growth and opportunity. I learned what I could from this dismal place, and within two years moved on to a position at least two steps up from what JJC made available to me.

pros: Great people, friendly environment, most people put the students first, beautiful campus, great location, lots of great lunch options nearby.
cons: Politics, lack of leadership, overspending, nepotism, Unions make this place a mess, HR doesn't help but instead protects the bad management
